key_insight: Using meta-learning to train handover policies across many cells enables fast per-cell adaptation that balances Conditional and Traditional HOs, reducing failures, delays, and signaling overhead in NextG O-RAN deployments.
problem_solved: Handover failures and delays in dense/high-frequency mobile networks and the trade-offs between Traditional Handover (THO) and Conditional Handover (CHO); lack of scalable, quickly adaptable HO policies across heterogeneous cells.
method: Meta-learning across base stations to learn a transferable initialization that can be fine-tuned with few samples per cell for fast, localized HO decisions.
Design and implementation as an O-RAN-compliant control xApp for closed-loop selection/execution between CHO and THO, accounting for signaling and resource costs.
Evaluation with large-scale (countrywide) mobility traces and simulations to demonstrate reduced failure rates, lower latency, and signaling/resource improvements versus baselines.
impact: Demonstrates a practical application of meta-learning for real-time network control and few-shot adaptation in production-like O-RAN systems, offering a template for ML-driven radio resource management and low-overhead deployments.
visual_elements: O-RAN architecture diagram highlighting the xApp performing meta-learned HO decisions and the feedback loop to RAN components
Bar chart or radar chart comparing THO, CHO, and the proposed method on metrics: HO failure rate, latency, signaling overhead, and resource reservation
Country map heatmap showing mobility traces and per-region performance gains (failure reduction / latency improvement)
Flow diagram of offline meta-training → online per-cell fine-tuning → runtime HO decision (CHO vs THO) with icons for latency and signaling
paper_title: Meta-Learning-Based Handover Management in NextG O-RAN
paper_authors: Michail Kalntis, George Iosifidis, José Suárez-Varela, Andra Lutu, Fernando A. Kuipers
